idioms.expression: faire une croix sur quelque chose
idioms.literal: to make a cross on something
idioms.meaning: to kiss something goodbye; give up on it
to pull a funny face; look surprised/put out

idioms.literal: to make a flower for someone

idioms.meaning: to blunder; put one’s foot in it

idioms.literal: to make the sensitive string vibrate
idioms.meaning: to strike a chord; play on someone’s emotions

idioms.expression: faire vivre un enfer à quelqu’un
idioms.literal: to make someone live a hell
to leave in the English way
idioms.meaning: to slip away without saying goodbye
to smoke a lot; to smoke like a chimney
to gain time; to buy time

idioms.literal: to throw money out of the windows
the matter is in the bag

idioms.expression: la moutarde lui monte au nez
idioms.literal: the mustard is going up his nose
idioms.meaning: he is losing his temper; he’s getting angry
it’s all over; we’re done for

idioms.expression: manger les pissenlits par la racine
idioms.literal: to eat dandelions by the root

idioms.meaning: to grab a quick bite; to eat on the run

idioms.expression: mettre la clef sous la porte
idioms.literal: to put the key under the door

idioms.meaning: to get hold of; to lay one’s hands on

idioms.expression: mettre les pieds dans le plat
idioms.literal: to put one’s feet in the dish
idioms.meaning: to blunder; to say something tactless

idioms.literal: to put someone in a box
idioms.meaning: to tease; to make fun of someone

idioms.expression: mon petit doigt me l’a dit
idioms.literal: my little finger told me so

idioms.expression: ne pas être dans son assiette
idioms.literal: not to be in one’s plate
idioms.meaning: to feel out of sorts; not oneself

idioms.literal: to no longer have a radish
idioms.meaning: to be skint; to be broke
with no one any the wiser

idioms.literal: to pay for the broken pots
idioms.meaning: to pay for the damage; to face the consequences
to lose one’s mind; to lose self-control

idioms.literal: to place a rabbit for someone

idioms.expression: prendre son courage à deux mains
idioms.literal: to take one’s courage in both hands

idioms.meaning: to mingle with a crowd; to work a crowd
to suffer a heavy defeat (election, business, etc.)
to skulk; to keep a low profile
to give a forced laugh; to not find something funny
to champ at the bit; to be impatient

idioms.literal: to be bored like a dead rat
to get on like dog and cat
idioms.meaning: to argue constantly; not to get along
to manage; to get by; to cope
to be at each other’s throats

idioms.literal: to sit down at the table
idioms.meaning: to confess; to spill the beans

idioms.expression: se mettre le doigt dans l’œil
idioms.literal: to put one’s finger in one’s eye
to bleed oneself from four veins
idioms.meaning: to make huge sacrifices; to sweat blood
to do nothing; to be idle

idioms.expression: se trouver nez à nez avec quelqu’un
idioms.literal: to find oneself nose to nose with someone
idioms.pronunciation: [s(ə) tʁu.ve ne a ne a.vɛk kɛl.kœ̃]

idioms.meaning: to stir up trouble; to create dissension

idioms.literal: to go out like a whirlwind
idioms.meaning: to rush out; to leave in a hurry
to corner someone with endless chatter
to last; to cope; to hold out

idioms.literal: to pull the chestnuts out of the fire
idioms.meaning: to do the hard work so someone else can benefit; or to be used
a futile act; a wasted effort

idioms.literal: a story to sleep standing up
idioms.meaning: a tall tale; a ridiculous story

idioms.expression: une truie n’y retrouverait pas ses petits
idioms.literal: even a sow couldn’t find her piglets there
idioms.pronunciation: [yn tʁɥi ni ʁ(ə).tʁu.v(ə).ʁɛ pɑ se p(ə).ti]

idioms.meaning: to go down fighting; not to give up easily
to see life through rose-tinted glasses

idioms.expression: voir le monde par le petit bout de la lorgnette
idioms.literal: to see the world through the small end of the spyglass
idioms.pronunciation: [vwaʁ lə mɔ̃d paʁ lə pə.ti bu d(ə) la lɔʁ.ɲɛt]
idioms.meaning: to be narrow; to have a distorted perspective

nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: because of; on account of
in the open air; outdoors
next to; beside
by dint of; by repeatedly using
in the short term
neglected; abandoned
sheltered; safely away
intended for; aimed at
aside; away from others
just like; as much as
right-side out; the right way around
toward; with regard to
inside out; upside down; back to front
at that time (in the past)
cramped; short of space
on time
ordinarily; as a rule
thanks to; under cover of
in someone’s face
at the same time
in fashion; fashionable
instead; in (its) place
in the long term
halfway between
in my/your/his/her opinion
from; starting from
hardly; barely
about; concerning; with regard to
about him/her/you/me
in time
seeing as; given that

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Après la pluie, le beau temps
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: After the rain, the nice weather
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: Every cloud has a silver lining; things will get better.
Oh my god!; Holy cow!
nonIdiomaticExpressions.notes: Informal exclamation of surprise, admiration, or frustration.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Appuyer là où ça fait mal
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To touch a sore spot; to hit a nerve.
Stop exaggerating!; Get off your high horse!
As we go along; gradually.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Avoir un poil dans la main
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To have a hair in the hand
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To be very lazy (so lazy that a hair has had time to grow there).
To have a hangover.
To be bummed out; to be annoyed or disappointed.
To be at rock bottom emotionally; to feel very down.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Avoir plusieurs cordes à son arc
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To have several strings to one's bow
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To have multiple skills or options to rely on.
To walk around aimlessly; to pace while waiting.
Good luck (in a difficult task); Be strong; Hang in there.
nonIdiomaticExpressions.notes: Used to wish someone strength for a challenge.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: Anyway...; In short...; Long story short...
nonIdiomaticExpressions.notes: Used to summarize or cut a story short.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: That sucks.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Ça coûte un bras / la peau des fesses
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: That costs an arm / the skin of the buttocks
nonIdiomaticExpressions.pronunciation: [sa kut œ̃ bʁa / la po de fɛs]
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: It costs an arm and a leg; It's extremely expensive.
nonIdiomaticExpressions.notes: The second version is more vulgar.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: Okay; Deal; That works for me.
That rings a bell.
That doesn't ring a bell; I'm not interested.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Ça n'a ni queue ni tête
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: That has neither tail nor head
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: It makes no sense whatsoever.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Ça ne casse pas trois pattes à un canard
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: It doesn't break three legs on a duck
nonIdiomaticExpressions.pronunciation: [sa nə kas pɑ tʁwa pat a œ̃ ka.naʁ]
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: It's nothing special; it's not all it's cracked up to be.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Ça ne mange pas de pain
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: It doesn't cost anything; There's no harm in trying.
Are you up for it?; Sound good?
That goes without saying.
It's fake; It's bogus; That's rubbish.
Totally; Exactly; I agree.
It's a godsend; It's a piece of cake.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: C'est la cerise sur le gâteau
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: It's the cherry on the cake
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: It's the icing on the cake (can be ironic).
That's nonsense; That's ridiculous.
It's not rocket science.
It's great!; It's awesome!

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To look for noon at 2 PM
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To overcomplicate things; to make things unnecessarily difficult.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Comme on fait son lit, on se couche
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: As one makes one's bed, one lies down
nonIdiomaticExpressions.pronunciation: [kɔm ɔ̃ fɛ sɔ̃ li ɔ̃ sə kuʃ]
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: You've made your bed, now lie in it.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To give a knock of thread
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To make a phone call.
To rest on one's laurels.
To declare one's love for someone.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To push in an open door
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To state the obvious; to preach to the choir.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: En long, en large et en travers
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: In long, in large and across
nonIdiomaticExpressions.pronunciation: [ɑ̃ lɔ̃ ɑ̃ laʁʒ e ɑ̃ tʁa.vɛʁ]
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: Inside and out; thoroughly; from every angle.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To make a whole cheese out of it
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To make a big deal out of something; to make a mountain out of a molehill.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Et mon cul, c'est du poulet ?
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: And my ass, is it chicken?
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: Yeah, right!; And I'm the Pope!; Do I look stupid?

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To make two strikes with one stone
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To kill two birds with one stone.
To beg for money.
To wait for a long time; to be kept waiting.
To be bitterly cold.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Faut pas pousser mémé dans les orties
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: You must not push grandma into the nettles
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: Don't push your luck; Don't go too far.
To be going downhill (health, situation); to be in a bad way.
Chin up!; Keep your spirits up!

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Il n'y a pas le feu au lac
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: There is no fire at the lake
nonIdiomaticExpressions.pronunciation: [il ni a pa lə fø o lak]
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: There's no rush; What's the hurry?
nonIdiomaticExpressions.notes: Originally Swiss French, but now common in France.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: It's raining cats and dogs.
I'm fed up; I've had enough.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Jeter un pavé dans la mare
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To throw a paving stone in the pond
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To cause a stir; to drop a bombshell.
A need to go to the toilet.
To sleep on it.
Forget it; Let it go; Drop it.
Walls have ears.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Mettre de l'eau dans son vin
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To put water in one's wine
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To tone it down; to be more moderate.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Mettre du beurre dans les épinards
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To put butter in the spinach
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To improve one's financial situation; to supplement one's income.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Mettre les points sur les i
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To put the dots on the i's
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To make things crystal clear; to dot the i's and cross the t's.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To put one's grain of salt
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To give one's (often unsolicited) opinion; to put one's two cents in.
Better late than never.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To get on one's big horses
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To get on one's high horse; to get angry.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Ne pas être sa tasse de thé
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To not be one's cup of tea
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: It's not my cup of tea.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Ne pas mettre tous ses œufs dans le même panier
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To not put all one's eggs in the same basket
nonIdiomaticExpressions.pronunciation: [nə pɑ mɛtʁ tu se.z‿ø dɑ̃ lə mɛm pa.nje]
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: Don't put all your eggs in one basket.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Ne pas y aller par quatre chemins
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To not go by four paths
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To not beat around the bush.
Right?; Isn't it?; Don't you?
Mind your own business.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: We keep each other in the current
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: We'll keep in touch; Let's keep each other updated.
No problem.
Not at all.
To wipe the slate clean; to forgive and forget.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To pass a bad quarter of an hour
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To have a rough time; to go through a difficult but brief experience.
To pull an all-nighter; to have a sleepless night.
To go nowhere; to spin one's wheels.
To rain cats and dogs.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: When one speaks of the wolf
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: Speak of the devil (and he shall appear).
What's up?; What's new?
To tell lies; to spin tall tales.
To butt in; to show up uninvited.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: Let's get back to our sheep
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: Let's get back to the subject at hand.
Cheers!

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To jump from the rooster to the donkey
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To jump from one topic to another completely unrelated one.
To worry oneself sick.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Se noyer dans un verre d'eau
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To drown in a glass of water
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To get overwhelmed by the smallest difficulty.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Se payer la tête de quelqu'un
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To make fun of someone; to pull someone's leg.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Se vendre comme des petits pains
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To sell like hotcakes.
To be the third wheel.
To bump into someone; to run into someone unexpectedly.
Exactly; Absolutely.
Suddenly; All at once.
Right away; Immediately.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Tout est bien qui finit bien
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: All is well that ends well
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: All's well that ends well.
Everyone; Everybody.
Everything is fine.
Tell me about it!; No kidding! (expresses strong agreement/lack of surprise)
One of these days.
There's no comparison; It's a no-brainer.
How are you?; Are you okay?
nonIdiomaticExpressions.notes: The most common greeting in French.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: So-so; alright.
So; As a result; Consequently.
nonIdiomaticExpressions.notes: Extremely common filler word in modern spoken French.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: Actually; In fact.
Nonsense; Whatever; Rubbish.
nonIdiomaticExpressions.notes: Used to dismiss something as absurd.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To have a big smile; to be beaming.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Il n'y a pas de lézard
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: There's no problem; no snag.
To be on strike.
To be out of it; to be completely spaced out.
Well done!; Hats off to you!

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To let the merino sheep piss
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To let things go; not to worry about it.
To annoy; to be a hassle. 'Se prendre la tête' means to overthink or get worked up.
Hi; Bye.
Hey!; Hi there!
nonIdiomaticExpressions.notes: Very informal, friendly, often used in writing.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: See you later.
nonIdiomaticExpressions.notes: 'À plus' is the very informal, abbreviated version.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: See you in a bit (implies you will see the person again the same day).
You're welcome.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Je vous en prie / Je t'en prie
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: You're welcome (more formal); Please; Go ahead.
To give the traditional cheek kisses as a greeting.
Meh; an expression of indifference or disappointment.
We'll see.
That's a pity; That's too bad.
Too bad; Never mind; Oh well.
All the better; That's great.
To not be bothered; to feel too lazy to do something.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To have the potato / the french fry
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To be full of energy; to feel great.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To take a rake for oneself
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To be rejected (romantically).

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To let go of the business
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To give up; to drop it.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Être à ramasser à la petite cuillère
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To be picked up with a small spoon
nonIdiomaticExpressions.pronunciation: [ɛtʁ a ʁa.mɑ.se a la pə.tit kɥi.jɛʁ]
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To be completely wiped out; to be emotionally or physically shattered.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Se faire rouler dans la farine
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To get oneself rolled in flour
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To be tricked; to be duped.
To fall into the trap.
No way!; You're kidding!; My foot!
To pull an all-nighter.
To get dressed up to the nines.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Avoir un chat dans la gorge
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To have a cat in the throat
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To have a frog in one's throat.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Quand les poules auront des dents
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: When pigs fly.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: La moutarde me monte au nez
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: The mustard is rising to my nose
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: I'm starting to get angry.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Il y a de l'eau dans le gaz
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: There is water in the gas
nonIdiomaticExpressions.pronunciation: [il i a də lo dɑ̃ lə ɡaz]
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: There's trouble brewing; there's tension in the air.
To swagger; to show off.
To turn a deaf ear.
Awful weather.
To have goosebumps.
To be at full throttle; to give it one's all; to be super busy.
To leave; to clear out.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Ne pas avoir sa langue dans sa poche
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To not have one's tongue in one's pocket
nonIdiomaticExpressions.pronunciation: [nə pɑ.z‿a.vwaʁ sa lɑ̃ɡ dɑ̃ sa pɔʃ]
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To be outspoken; to not be afraid to speak one's mind.
To hang on someone's every word.
To flop; to be a complete failure (for a show, event).

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Avoir un polichinelle dans le tiroir
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To have a Pulcinella in the drawer
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To have a bun in the oven; to be pregnant.
To be self-absorbed; navel-gazing.
Look no further.
To veto something.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To have the wind in the stern
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To be on a roll; to be thriving.
To be a complete waste of time and effort (like talking to a brick wall).

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To beat one's eye with it
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To not give a damn.
nonIdiomaticExpressions.notes: Polite alternative to more vulgar expressions.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: That's annoying me; I'm sick of it.
To piss off; to be a pain in the ass.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Être au bout de sa vie
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To be at the end of one's life
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To be completely exhausted; to be done with it all (hyperbolic).

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To be on one's little cloud
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To be on cloud nine; to be blissfully happy and detached from reality.
In a jiffy; in no time at all.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Avoir la tête dans le cul
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To have one's head in the ass
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To be groggy, tired, not with it (especially in the morning).
To be careful; to watch out.
To keep someone posted/updated.
No kidding; Seriously.
To be starving.
To be in deep trouble.
To sleep in; to have a lie-in.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To have a blow from a bar
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To suddenly feel exhausted.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Il/Elle me court sur le haricot
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: He/She is getting on my nerves.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To be well-behaved like a picture
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To be as good as gold (usually said of children).

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Ne rien savoir faire de ses dix doigts
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To not know how to do anything with one's ten fingers
nonIdiomaticExpressions.pronunciation: [nə ʁjɛ̃ sa.vwaʁ fɛʁ də se di dwa]
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To be completely useless with one's hands.
To claim victory (often prematurely).
To step up one's efforts; to work twice as fast.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To blow a fuse / a cable
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To blow a gasket; to lose it completely.
To be a know-it-all.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Se jeter dans la gueule du loup
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To throw oneself into the wolf's mouth
nonIdiomaticExpressions.pronunciation: [sə ʒə.te dɑ̃ la ɡœl dy lu]
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To walk right into the lion's den.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Avoir le cul bordé de nouilles
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To have one's ass lined with noodles
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To be extremely lucky.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Être au four et au moulin
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To be at the oven and at the mill
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To be in two places at once; to be doing many things simultaneously.
To fizzle out; to fail to last.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Ce n'est pas la porte à côté
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: It's not the door next door
nonIdiomaticExpressions.pronunciation: [sə n‿ɛ pɑ la pɔʁt a ko.te]
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: It's not exactly close by.
Phew!
Ouch!
To be overly sentimental or romantic.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Prendre ses jambes à son cou
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To take one's legs to one's neck
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To run for one's life; to take to one's heels.
There's a catch; something's fishy.
To stick together; to support each other.
To be a huge success; to be a smash hit.
To ride the wave of success or a trend.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To put the flea in the ear
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To make someone suspicious; to plant a seed of doubt.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To not lead wide of it
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To be ill at ease; to be scared or intimidated.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To have a heart of stone
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To be cold-hearted.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Il n'y a pas un chat
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: There's not a soul here; the place is empty.
To sort things out; to separate the good from the bad.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Ne pas savoir sur quel pied danser
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To not know on which foot to dance
nonIdiomaticExpressions.pronunciation: [nə pa sa.vwaʁ syʁ kɛl pje dɑ̃.se]
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To not know how to act or what to think.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To be pulled by four pins
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To be dressed to the nines; to be impeccably dressed.
To lose one's bearings; to become flustered or confused.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: À tes souhaits / À vos souhaits
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: Bless you (after a sneeze).

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To have the ball in the stomach
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To have a knot in one's stomach (from stress or fear).

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To cost the skin of the buttocks
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To cost an arm and a leg.
To be driven crazy; to get furious.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To have had one's supper of it
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To have had enough of something; to be sick of it.
To be as easy as pie.
To write a bad check.
To bribe someone; to grease someone's palm.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Il ne faut pas réveiller le chat qui dort
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: One must not wake the sleeping cat
nonIdiomaticExpressions.pronunciation: [il nə fo pa ʁe.vɛ.je lə ʃa ki dɔʁ]
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: Let sleeping dogs lie.
To leave someone in the lurch.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To not see a drop in it
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To not be able to see a thing.
To deceive or trick someone.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Tirer les plans sur la comète
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To draw plans on the comet
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To build castles in the air; to make unrealistic plans.

nonIdiomaticExpressions.expression: Tuer la poule aux œufs d'or
nonIdiomaticExpressions.literal: To kill the hen with the golden eggs
nonIdiomaticExpressions.meaning: To kill the goose that lays the golden eggs.
To have the blues; to feel down.
To be ravenously hungry.
